posts.name: Noam Novo
posts.cooked:
Hey

I’m interested in learning about how other teams design their palate cuts and overall palette designs. What factors do you typically consider when creating these designs, and how do you ensure they’re structurally sound and won’t break under pressure? I’d appreciate any insights you can share on this topic!

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Gonna suggest rechecking your translation. For us, “palette” tends to refer to what a painter puts their colored paint on. I don’t think that’s what you meant.

Are you referring to weight-reduction patterns machine on bellypans and drive rails?

posts.name: Noam Novo
posts.cooked: You right, I’m just tired and made a mistake

looks and vibess

on a more serious note, I know the Grasshoppers (95) open build thread has some posts specifically about FEA(i think that’s the acronym?) that @JamesCH95 goes fairly in depth about.

for our robot specifically, the intake plates were lightened by starting with the silhouette of the plate, then adding in each piece. the process of adding support back simply consists of sketching lines from important c-c’s that would see concentrated stress in the area (ie. bearing hole to bearing hole). when you have your supports sketched, you can use the Thin-Extrude feature in SOLIDWORKS (onshape probably has an equivalent) to define the width of each beam (for 1/4" aluminum we used 1/4" wide lines.)

Onshape however has a featurescript called “lighten featurescript” that lets you give some parameters and mathematically lightens your part for you. downsides being that now your part doesn’t have personality from being pocketed by hand

I used 2910’s 2023 end effector as a rough reference of how things should look while lightening our team’s intake this year IMG_20240120_155913610 1920×1440 569 KB IMG_20240225_094912764 1920×2560 412 KB notice how there is more material around the leading edge of the intake- that is because 1. it surrounds a hole for a bearing, 2. that part of the intake hits the ground, and 3. it is the most likely spot to be bent / damaged in competition.

IMG_20240120_155913610 1920×1440 569 KB

IMG_20240120_155913610 1920×1440 569 KB

IMG_20240225_094912764 1920×2560 412 KB

IMG_20240225_094912764 1920×2560 412 KB

important note if you lighten by hand: fillets make anything look good

posts.name: Ian
posts.cooked: For the most part, offset your holes and connect them. Looking at other people’s designs is a good starting point. If you have large hole-free areas generally you isogrid them, which prevents a bending motion on the plate primarily, half pocketing also works good for this.

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked:
V1 with no cheesing: IMG_6371 4032×3024 2.71 MB V2 where we cheesed: IMG_6728 909×1518 261 KB

IMG_6371 4032×3024 2.71 MB

IMG_6371 4032×3024 2.71 MB

IMG_6728 909×1518 261 KB

IMG_6728 909×1518 261 KB

ultimately my advice would be find a pattern of a shape that looks nice ideally, apply it in lines, and make sure you leave some support and some “infill” around any holes so they don’t break. they’re fun parts to make too so fabrication will hopefully be happy with you!

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Onshape lightening macro is the bees knees.

I don’t do much device specific FEA for our robots. It’s super hard to quantify loads on a robot enough to make am absolute determination with any confidence. I would strongly caution any team similarly. FEA is good for making relative determinations between designs, which is often good enough for FRC .

If anyone does want some guidance on FEA please post it on CD and tag me, I am happy to help with specific models.

@Noam6738 to specifically answer your question: experience and testing. We will make our best guess and then literally slam the intake into a wall at full speed and fix whatever breaks. There is video and high-speed video of this in our build threads.

While pocketing is brought up a lot and does help, what is more important is reducing all the weight in the first place before pocketing. Often, the outside dimensions can be reduced on a plate without affecting functionality, which is free weight savings. Small thing is lighter than big thing, so why do big thing when you don’t get any benefit for doing so. So yes, literally cut corners and make the parts as minimal as possible, then pocket them for the last bit of weight savings. Thin plates can be quite strong as long as bending loads are avoided.

Noam6738:

how do you ensure they’re structurally sound and won’t break under pressure?

By avoiding bending loads whenever. FRC parts typically break through bending, or sometimes torsion because both loading scenarios create long lever arms that result in large moments and stresses. If reinforcements for any stucture is needed, it is much better to load beams or cables in pure tension or compression rather than adding more material under bending. If bending is unavoidable, prioritize increasing the 2nd moment area rather than throwing material in useless locations. Most pocketing patters directly connect all high load points such as screws and bearings because this ensures that the struts are loaded in pure tension or compression rather than other bad pocketing patterns which can load struts in bending.

Also, make sure you are not sacrificing stiffness when trying to build light. A 125lb robot that is extremely stiff will outperform a 90 pound bot with stiffness issues because the stiff robot will do what your drivers and software tells them to do. Robots with stiffness issues will remove many of the benefits that good software and drivers provide because it physically can’t do what it is told to do.

I also wouldn’t bother with FEA unless you know what you are doing, its very easy to make FEA give garbage results and extremely hard to accurately model most loading conditions which makes it often not a practical tool for FRC apart from getting pretty pictures.

posts.name: Ian
posts.cooked:
If bending is unavoidable

…use polycarb

polycarbonate would have been awful for an intake like ours. you can retain the motor mounting, belt tensions, and especially the loctite. every hole on those 2 plates posted earlier were threaded.

sidenote, why are most of your replies just awful takes?

I would suggest reading the entire post before dropping a 1-liner, especially when it is wrong.

Polycarb ain’t magic and if you use it in high-load scenarios, you will really quickly learn why stiffness matters the hard way. Polycarb (and other low elastic modulus materials) are really only good at one thing, and that’s preventing things from getting loaded, but only if you don’t really care about stiffness for whatever reasons. And in cases where it is subject to high static loads, well, polycarb isn’t that strong and I have seen quite a few polycarb breaks because like all materials, it has significant limitations.

Its very common for beams to be loaded in bending including on drivetrains, elevators and arms and using polycarb in that scenario is a recipe for disaster. Oftentimes, it is not possible or practical to eliminate the bending moments with tensile members, which is then where your best bet is to increase the 2nd moment area.

Hey, I did some CAD for my team this year so I’ll be happy to help. First of all we sketch all the features that we need for example motors, bearings and bolts. After we figure all these out we make up the outline of the plate so it matches our need. After we have a general shape we add offsets to the outline and all holes and then add slots between features to add strength where we believe it’s needed. After we finish we finish we run a stress analysis to make sure our predictions were right.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked: Thinner material without extraneous pocketing > thicker material with an extra hour of design and machining time. Bent flanges are great if you can make them.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: @TrackpadCAD ’s comment may not be relevant to the situations you were imagining, but he’s not wrong. Many of the mechanisms that are most likely to see high bending loads don’t need rigidity. I’m particularly thinking about over bumper intakes here where you can either build heavy intake that will take the collision and transmit the forces to your drivebase which will also need to be very strong, or you can build a light flexible intake that pops back into shape after a collision. I’d much rather have the flexible intake. There are also applications like the sector gears on our shooter this year where we need fairly high rigidity in the plane of the plate, but flexibility normal to that plane will reduce the possibility of binding, as well as reducing the likelihood of damage due to collisions and reducing weight.

posts.name: Camren
posts.cooked:
Alex_Y:

increasing the 2nd moment area

Can’t stress this enough, I saw a lot of bent 1x2x.125" chassis tubes bent this year. Our team used a 1.5" x 3" x .125" Formed Channel without any issues.

Consider lighter material with flanges instead of heavy flat plates.

posts.name: Kieran Jarvis
posts.cooked: Obviously you’re responding to a 4 word blanket statement but this can only be true when the entire system is capable of withstanding the forces. I designed a similar intake for Ri3D where we added PC plates between the two outer intake plates, increasing 2nd moment area in that direction. They were secured to the side plates using zipties, which broke on a big enough impact. However, fixing this would simply increase the forces on the arm it’s attached to, and if that survives then it would be the superstructure, etc, but the leverage of the arm increases the forces that must be withstood here. So by making a rigid intake, you need to beef up the rest of the robot too. And in this age i reckon its almost (almost!) impossible to survive every external impact, so why not have the part that breaks be the easiest one to replace, too?

Intakes are their own things and yea poly is often a good idea but most other mechanisms care a lot about stiffness and aren’t subject to bending moments. Yea polycarb works on intakes due to the low stiffness preventing loading the members on side impacts, but many mechanisms such as the drivetrain frame itself, arms, and elevators care a lot about stiffness and are subject to large bending moments in which the only practical solution is to use beams and the best option to increase the strength in such cases is to increase 2nd moment area.

And even then, there are other important steps to mitigate impact damage than just running PC. Generally the most effective way of preventing impact damage is to make the intake retract on intake through its actuation geometry, which teams have been designing for years because even PC intakes that don’t retract can easily be taken out by a front hit. And even them, some teams have found ways to make stiff intakes work with notably 1678 using 3/8in plate for an OTB intake this year because it actually can take such forces when designed correctly.

but it doesn’t look as cool

to sell it to teams just say it’s something to talk to judges about

Alex_Y:

And even them, some teams have found ways to make stiff intakes work with notably 1678 using 3/8in plate for an OTB intake this year because it actually can take such forces when designed correctly.

I believe they’ve switched to 1/4" polycarb with 1/16" aluminum.
